newsitem.title: CHINA: HK stocks end sharply lower as properties tumble.
newsitem.headline: HK stocks end sharply lower as properties tumble.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks tumbled to a sharply lower close on Friday as uncertainty about government plans to curb rising real estate prices rattled property stocks.

An initial rally of 123.79 points, following new record highs on Wall Street overnight, were quickly wiped out and the Hang Seng Index closed on a loss of 232.77 points, or 1.55 percent, at 14,822.97 after reaching a session low of 14,727.48.

"Developers are very weak and all the other sectors are doing very little," said Miles Remington, sales trader at SocGen-Crosby Securities. "Red chips, which were driving the market before, are going off."
The red chip China-Affiliated Corporations Index tumbled to a low of 3,334.71 before ending the session up 3.93 points, or 0.12 percent, at 3,417.43.
Total turnover was HK$22.51 billion compared with HK$24.5 billion on Thursday.
The Hang Seng Index ended the abbreviated two-day week, the first trading sessions under Chinese rule, on a loss of 373.82 points, or 2.46 percent.
The final trading day under British rule last Friday saw Hang Seng Index rise to a record closing high of 15,196.79.
Investors had hoped that after a three-day holiday to mark Hong Kong's July 1 return to Chinese rule, the market would usher in a new era under China with strong gains.
But those plans were dashed when Hong Kong's new Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa revealed plans on Tuesday to increase housing supply in an effort to deal with rising property prices.
"Now we are worried about the property sector which has dragged the index down," said Alex Wong, technical analyst at Dharmala Securities.
Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd tumbled HK$2.00 to HK$71.75 and Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd slid HK$2.50 to HK$86.25.

Remington said the property sector looked oversold but more downside could lie ahead with some investors now negative on a three-month view since Tung is only expected to reveal specific details of his housing plans in a policy statement in October.
Henderson Land Development Co Ltd managed to shed its losses to end up HK$0.25 at HK$66.00 after falling to a low of HK$63.75.
HSBC Holdings Plc forged ahead to hit an all-time high of HK$243.00 before closing up HK$3.00 at HK$241.00.
July Hang Seng Index futures closed down 70 points at 14,830.
